properties.media:imagetext:
Mr. Bixby
.-
2 - ,
September 22, 1937
Undoubtedly the Generalissimo hoped for the maximum of time
to complete his preparations and was ready to go to a considerable length
to stall
off the hour of the showdown,
but I do not think that for the
past two years he had any expectation of avoiding it by putting up any fake
show and final agreement which would involve any material
expansion of the
Japanese sphere
of influence in China.
In other words I do not think, as
you say,
that
the Chinese patience became exhausted, but rather that the
Japanese,
Judging the situation correctly, forced the issue when they did
instead of
giving
the General any more time to prepare.
This is precisely
what the Central Powers did in 1914 when France and Russia were preparing
for a showdown in
1916 or later.
There is considerable talk here and in the papers to the
effect that the Chinese Government was dragged into this war through pres-
public opinion and inability to restrain the army leaders and the
masses of the people any longen.
This theory does not jibe with the fact
of the very complete and ample preparation which was made for this eventu-
ality.
Obviously
there was a very great public reaction against Japan and
probably wide-spread demand for forfeful action, but this undoubtedly could
have been controlled by the Government if that had been their policy.
seems more likely
It
that in Japan the people were dragged in by the army lead-
ers and this may
have important repercussions later.
I never could see why it was that there was such wide-spread
opinion among the "China hands"
that the next incident would not
seriously
involve Shanghai.
There were two controlling reasons,
to my mind, why the
Japanese had to attack at Shanghai.
One was
the necessity of their protect-
ing their great number of nationals there from mob violence, and the second
was the important economic consequence to China of
paralizing and control-
ling its most important commercial city.
It was equally certain that the
Chinese would resist any military activity around Shanghai although every-
body,
including the Japanese, miscalculated the vigor of the Chinese resist-
ance around that point.
In any case, however,
it seemed to me,
and I re-
member so telling Bond here in July,
that far
from being a safe haven, I
thought the International Settlement might become perhaps the most dangerous
place to be in China.
It must be only a question of time before antipathy
towards Japan will turn into antipathy
towards all foreigners--if external
aid is not forthcoming.
I am not going to be
foolish enough to try
to predict the
future
course of events other than to say that if my theories as above set
forth are correct,
it is a certainty
that the Chinese resistance will be
vigorous and long drawn out.
Much must depend on the extent of the military
supplies
which they have been able to accumulate during the last two or
years,
three
and their ability to obtain new supplies in spite of the coastal block-
ade by Japan.
OnLy
time will show the answer to these questions and it seems
to me that gasoline supplies will be a vital factor since, unless I am mistaken,
there is no gasoline production in China, and it would be very difficult at
present
to bring
this in except
through
channels which the Japanese will al-
most certainly be successful in blockading.
However, experience has shown
